description: Borrowed from Ecclesiastical Latin discalceātus (“barefoot”)  +‎ -ed, rendering French déchaussé. Surface etymology dis- +‎ calced.

entries.meaning: (Roman Catholicism) Pertaining to a religious order that historically forswore the wearing of shoes. [from 17th c.]
examples: Brother John is a member of the Discalced Carmelites.

entries.meaning: (formal, more generally) Shoeless; without shoes on; barefoot, or wearing sandals rather than shoes. [from 19th c.]
